messages.content: 9-1-1, what's your emergency?
Hi, this is the Angus Police. I have a bear mauling. I'm out on the trail.
You have a young girl who was mauled by a bear and is in bad shape?
Yes, we need paramedics. I just reported it to somebody else who's going to be calling 911.
Okay, I'm going to transfer you through to the medics, or did you already talk to them?
I have not talked to anybody yet.
Okay, where are you located?
To access us, the easiest way is to go to the Hilltop Ski Area and go down the gas line trail to where it meets Campbell Creek.
So you're closest to Hilltop Ski Area?
Yes.
Okay, hold on one second. Now that I've got your location, I need to transfer you through to the medics.
Thank you.
Can you still hear me?
Yes.
Fire paramedics, what's the location of the emergency?
It is on Rovers Run Trail, and the best way to access that is by the gas line trail.
Okay, what's the problem? Tell me exactly what happened.
I just came across a young girl who was mauled by a bear.
All right. I'm going to ask you some questions about her while my partner gets help started. How old is she?
I believe she's about 15 or 16 years old.
Is she conscious? Is she breathing?
She is breathing heavily, yes.
When did this happen?
Within the last probably 15 to 20 minutes.
Is there any serious bleeding?
Yes, severe bleeding.
Are you with her right now?
I am, we're in close proximity to where it happened.
What kind of injuries does she have?
It's hard to tell, it's dark, and I dropped my bike down the trail. I don't have a light.
Is the animal still nearby?
Not that I know of. I hope it's gone away.
How far are you from Campbell Airstrip Road?
If you came up Campbell-Airstrip Road, you would access us by the South Bivouac Trailhead.
Sir, listen, we understand. How far in are you, about a quarter mile?
Yes, we're going to come in off the South Bivouac Trailhead.
Okay. Our first caller gave us that information and is waiting there for us.
Okay, go in the trailhead, and about 100 yards down the trail, there's a right-hand turn.
Okay, I got it. Now that I've kind of got where you are, hold on while we get the paramedics there.
Okay, thank you.
Does she have any serious bleeding?
Yes, I would say so.
What I want you to do is get a clean, dry cloth or towel, place it on the wound, and press it down firmly without lifting it up to look.
I don't know exactly where the wound is, that's the problem.
Can you ask her where she thinks she's hurt?
Do you know where you're hurt?
Sir, listen, I have a quick question. How close are you to the Campbell Airstrip?
We are farther than the actual airstrip. They need to go farther up the road.
How far up the road from the Campbell Airstrip?
I would say a mile and a half, two miles. There will be two obvious trailheads with big wooden signs.
So they're marked north and south?
Yes, they want to go into South Bivouac Trailhead.
Once they get to the South Bivouac parking lot, they're going to go down the trail and look to the right for a steep dirt trail?
Yes, it leads to a footbridge that crosses the creek, then take a right onto the trail. They should have bear protection.
We're getting the cops to come out there with us.
Okay, you're doing great. Just hang in there.
Is the bear still there?
Not that I know of, but it's dark.
Do you know what kind of bear it was?
I don't know.
Just stay awake and stay alert. Is she breathing regularly?
Yes, heavy breathing. She's very conscious.
Can you hear anybody out there?
No, but there's a bike race going on, so someone might pass by soon. I'll have them flag the paramedics.
Okay, that's good. Let me know if anything changes.
Hey, can you stop, please? We have a bear attack. The paramedics are coming to South Bivouac Trailhead.
You're doing awesome. Just keep calm.
Okay, a biker is going up to direct them down to us.
Great. How is she doing?
She seems to be doing okay, still conscious and able to move a bit.
Okay, just keep her still, we don't want her moving around.
I had to move her a bit from the attack spot but will keep her still now.
You're doing great. Do you know how far up Campbell Airstrip Road the trailhead is?
About a mile and a half to two miles. If they start going uphill, they've gone past it.
We've got officers escorting the medics in right now.
Good, that should help. We've got another biker arriving.
Is that another biker?
Yes, they are here to help with flagging down the paramedics.
Great. Just keep her as still as possible.
We have an EMT here now who's assessing her injuries.
That's good. What injuries can you identify now?
A puncture wound to the face and some trauma to the inner thigh.
Can you keep a clean, dry cloth on the wound with pressure?
The EMT is handling it. The wounds don't seem to be bleeding too badly.
Okay, good. Just keep her calm and still.
She's doing okay, breathing more steadily now.
Let me know if anything changes with her condition.
Will do. There seems to be another wound on her back, above her left buttock.
Okay, just make sure she stays still.
She's doing great. The medics should be here soon.
You're doing a great job. Can you see if the bear did any other damage?
It's hard to tell, but it looks like a puncture wound to her throat area.
We need to assure her that help is on the way.
She knows, she's just trying to stay calm. The medics should be here anytime now.
Okay, let me know when they arrive.
Will do.
Are you still there?
Yes, the medics have arrived with the police.
Okay, I'm going to let you go so you can talk to them. Thank you for helping her.
Thank you, goodbye.
